perturbation.original_text:
(b) This Agreement may be terminated at any time by either party, effective immediately upon written notice, if the other party: (i) becomes
insolvent; (ii) files a petition in bankruptcy; or (iii) makes an assignment for the benefit of its creditors. Either party may terminate this
Agreement upon written notice if the other party materially breaches this Agreement and fails to cure such breach within thirty (30) days
after the date that it receives written notice of such breach from the non-breaching party.
perturbation.changed_text:
(b) This Agreement may be terminated at any time by either party, effective immediately upon written notice, if the other party: (i) becomes
insolvent; (ii) files a petition in bankruptcy; or (iii) makes an assignment for the benefit of its creditors. Either party may terminate this
Agreement upon written notice if the other party materially breaches this Agreement and fails to cure such breach within ten (10) days
after the date that it receives written notice of such breach from the non-breaching party.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the cure period for a material breach from 30 days to 10 days is a legal contradiction. New York law, which governs this agreement, generally requires a reasonable opportunity to cure a breach, and 10 days may be deemed unreasonably short depending on the nature and complexity of the breach, thus making the clause potentially unenforceable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: New York contract law principles regarding reasonable opportunity to cure a breach.

perturbation.original_text:
(b) Restrictions. Each party agrees that, during the Term and for two (2) years thereafter: (i) it will not disclose to any third party any
Confidential Information disclosed to it by the other party except as expressly permitted in this Agreement; (ii) it will only permit access to
Confidential Information of the disclosing party to those of its employees or authorized representatives or advisors (including, without limitation,
the receiving party’s auditors, accountants, and attorneys) having a need to know and who, prior to obtaining such access, are legally bound to
protect the disclosing party’s Confidential Information at least to the same extent as set forth herein
perturbation.changed_text:
(b) Restrictions. Each party agrees that, during the Term and for one (1) year thereafter: (i) it will not disclose to any third party any
Confidential Information disclosed to it by the other party except as expressly permitted in this Agreement; (ii) it will only permit access to
Confidential Information of the disclosing party to those of its employees or authorized representatives or advisors (including, without limitation,
the receiving party’s auditors, accountants, and attorneys) having a need to know and who, prior to obtaining such access, are legally bound to
protect the disclosing party’s Confidential Information at least to the same extent as set forth herein
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the confidentiality period to one year may be insufficient to protect trade secrets or other highly sensitive confidential information, potentially conflicting with established legal standards for trade secret protection under New York law, which often require a longer period of protection to remain commercially viable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: New York trade secret law and reasonable measures to protect trade secrets.

perturbation.original_text:
(k) Notice. Any notice required or permitted by this Agreement shall be in writing and shall be delivered as follows, with notice deemed
given upon receipt or refusal: (i) by overnight courier service; (ii) hand delivery; or (iii) by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested.
perturbation.changed_text:
(k) Notice. Any notice required or permitted by this Agreement shall be in writing and shall be delivered as follows, with notice deemed
given upon dispatch: (i) by overnight courier service; (ii) hand delivery; or (iii) by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested.
perturbation.explanation: Changing the notice provision to deem notice 'given upon dispatch' rather than 'upon receipt or refusal' creates a legal contradiction. Under New York law, for certain critical notices (e.g., notice of breach, termination), receipt is often required to ensure the other party is actually aware of the notice. Dispatch alone may not be sufficient, especially if the notice is lost or delayed, potentially leading to disputes over whether proper notice was given.
perturbation.contradicted_law: New York contract law principles regarding adequate notice and due process.
